message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: public E reduceLeft(BiFunction<? super E, ? super E, ? extends E> mapper){
    if (this.isEmpty())
    {
        return null;
    }
    Iterator<E> iterator = this.iterator();
    E first = iterator.next();
    while (iterator.hasNext())
    {
        first = mapper.apply(first, iterator.next());
    }
    return first;
}
<<<explanation>>>: In Java, you can't have lower-bounded type variables like in Scala. Therefore, you can't directly translate the Scala code to Java. However, you can achieve a similar effect by using a BiFunction with the same type for all three type parameters. This will allow you to apply the function to the first element and each subsequent element in the collection. The result of the function application is then used as the first argument for the next application, and so on, until all elements have been processed. This is essentially what the reduceLeft method does in Scala.
